question: Question_07_(b)
statement:
\textbf{Full-Solution Problems}. In questions 4â12, justify your
answers and \textbf{show all your work}. If a box is provided, write
your final answer there. \textbf{Unless otherwise indicated,
simplification of numerical answers is required in these questions}.

Evaluate $\displaystyle \int_{-1}^{1} \frac{dx}{(x^2+1)^3}$. You may use
the result of part (a) above, whether or not you completed that problem.
sols:
We want to be able to use part (a), so we need some way of converting
the polynomial into something involving trigonometric functions. In
particular, recall that

$\displaystyle \tan^2 \theta +1 = \sec^2 \theta$

so let's try the substitution $\displaystyle x = \tan \theta$, so
$\displaystyle dx = \sec^2 \theta \ d\theta$, and the boundaries of
integration change according to
$\displaystyle x = -1 = \tan\theta \Rightarrow \theta = -\pi/4$ and
$\displaystyle x = 1 =\tan \theta \Rightarrow \theta =  \pi/4$. Then,
using symmetry at the end, as the resulting function is even, we see
that

\begin{align*}
\int_{-1}^{1} \frac{dx}{(x^2+1)^3} &= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{(\tan^2\theta+1)^3} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{(\sec^2\theta)^3} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{\sec^2\theta}{\sec^6\theta} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \frac{1}{\sec^4\theta} \ d\theta \\
&= \int_{-\pi/4}^{\pi/4} \cos^4\theta \ d\theta \\
&= 2\int_{0}^{\pi/4} \cos^4\theta \ d\theta \\
&= 2\left(\frac{8+3\pi}{32}\right) \\
&= \frac{8+3\pi}{16}\end{align*}

polynomial turn into something that looks like a trigonometric function?
